It is widely understood that the wage gap is not entirely due to gender discrimination. There are many ways to look at numbers, and the gap is narrowing as workers compare to similar levels of education, occupation and experience. For example, nurses and fund secretaries enjoy closer pay parity. However, the gap still exists. A 2012 report by the American Association of University Women found a "unexplained" pay gap of 7 per cent among full-time workers one year after their graduation from college in 2009, even when they made similar career and educational decisions. Part of it is the choice of profession, research suggests. More women hold less paid jobs than men, often choosing jobs as receptionists, teachers and nurses in primary schools, for example, while men disproportionately choose jobs as truck drivers, managers and software engineers. Another factor is the time taken by women to have and care for children.
